* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy merchandise ordered by her customers

loans.name: Jahel

texts.en:
Jahel works hard to support her family. She is married and has a sari-sari (general) store business in the Philippines.

Jahel requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell in her sari-sari (general) store.

Jahel has been in this business for four years.

In the future, Jahel would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy works hard to support her family. Mercy is married and has a fishing/fish vending business in the Philippines.

Mercy requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase materials for the maintenance of her fishing boat.

Mercy has been in this business for 10 years now.

In the future, Mercy would like to save money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to pay for materials to maintain her fishing boat

loans.name: Herminia

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Herminia works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and earns additional income from food vending.  Herminia is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell for her general store business.

Herminia has been sustaining her business activities through her past seven loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of building and expanding her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional stock to sell

loans.name: Anabelle

texts.en:
Anabelle is 52 years old and married. She has two children.

Anabelle works hard to provide for her family. She runs a buying and selling nipa (woven palm mats used for house construction and repair) business in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 29500 loan through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell.

Anabelle has borrowed and repaid 13 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the buy and sell nipa (woven palm mats used for house construction and repair) business for 13 years and also earns an income from a pharmacy.

Anabelle aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional inventory to sell.

loans.name: Melinda

texts.en:
Melinda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has an ice cream making business in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 24,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients for her ice cream business.

Melinda has been in this business for 21 years. She earns additional income from a tricycle service.

Melinda has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her ice cream.

loans.name: Nelda

texts.en:
Nelda is married with four children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Nelda is 40 years old and has three children who are in school.

Nelda has a food vending business in the Philippines. Nelda requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional ingredients for her food production business.

Nelda has been in this business for 20 years. In the future, Nelda would like to save money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Tsengelmaa

texts.en: Mrs. Tsengelmaa is 42 years old and lives with her husband and her daughter in a small house in Songinohairhan district, Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband's name is Gansuh. He is 42 yrs old. He purchases old and broken cars, repairs and then sells them for a higher price. Her daughter goes to secondary school. She worked at a private tailoring company as an assistant for 20 years. She was laid off from work in 2010. She has been unemployed since then. She is planning to start her own business manufacturing souvenirs, slippers and key chains. She has manufactured a few by order and people really liked them. She is requesting 1,500,000 MNT to purchase inventory and machinery for her souvenir production business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory and machinery for her souvenir production business

loans.name: Noemie

texts.en:
Noemie is 31 years old and married with two children.

Noemie works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stocks to sell.

Noemie has borrowed and repaid 20 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 12 years and earns additional income from raising pigs.

Noemie aspires to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock to sell

loans.name: Nonalyn

texts.en:
Nonalyn is 21 years old and single.

Nonalyn works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 11000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stocks to sell in her general store.

Nonalyn has borrowed and paid 5 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 3 years and also earns an income from raising pigs.

Nonalyn aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks to sell in her general store

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is 48 years old and married with four children.

She earns a living by farming vegetables in the Philippines. Judith is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Judith has been farming vegetables for eight years and earns additional income from raising livestock.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilzers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fish vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to buy additional fish to sell for her fish vending business.

Nida has been in this business for 20 years. Nida earns more income from ice cream vending and raising pigs.

Nida has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money so she can afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional fish to sell

loans.name: Adrianus

texts.en:
Adrianus is a 52-year-old widower. His wife died about six years ago. He has four children from his marriage. Two of his children are married and live on another island and the other two children are still living with him and are attending school. To support his family, Adrianus initiated a repair shop business four years ago.
 
Adrianus was thinking about to improving his business by adding more spare parts. Therefore, he submitted a loan application to request IDR 7,500,000 from TLM. He plans to spend the loan on spark plugs, inner tubes, etc. Adrianus is expecting that this loan will help him improve his business and family life.

loans.use: to buy spark plugs, inner tubes, etc.

loans.name: Remy

texts.en:
Remy is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fish vending and crabs business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 30000 through NWTF to purchase more fish and crabs to sell for her business.Remy has been in this business for 18 years. Remy earns more income from fishing and raising pigs.

Remy has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough to provide a secure future for her family in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more fish and crabs to sell.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda works hard to support her family. Rosalinda is married and has a food vending business in the Philippines.

Rosalinda requested a PHP 10000 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business. Rosalinda has been in this business for 5 years now. In the future, Rosalinda would like to save money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: buy ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Salve

texts.en:
As a married parent of 4 children, Salve works hard to support her family.

She has a buying and selling rice grains business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a general store and farming rice. Salve is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to buy additional sacks of grains to sell for her buying and selling rice grains business.

Salve has been sustaining her business activities through her past 28 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional sacks of grains to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy chemical fertilizers for growing rice

loans.name: Ruqaya

texts.en:
Due to cultural reasons, Ruqaya prefers that her photo not be on the Internet; thus, the above photo is of her husband. Ruqaya is a 23-year-old married woman who supports three family members from Jabal Al-Hussain, Amman, Jordan. 

Ruqaya is requesting a loan of 500 JOD to buy clothes to resell. She has been selling her products in the area with a group of the women, but now she wants to sell clothes on her own. She hopes in the future to expand her business by opening a shop with her husband. As a result, she hopes to be able to improve her living standard and to continue supporting her sons' education.

Since Ruqaya is under 30 years old her loan is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: to buy clothes to resell

loans.name: Swzan

texts.en:
Swzan is a 19-year-old married woman from Al Khaledieh, Al Mafraq, Jordan. She is requesting a loan of 400 JD to buy foodstuffs in her store. 

She hopes in the future to increase her products and her income and to buy a new home for her family.

Since Swzan is under 30 years old, her loan is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy furniture and other household items.

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
Due to cultural reasons, Zainab prefers that her photo is not on the Internet. Thus, the above photo is of her husband. Zainab is a 28-year-old married woman who has 2 family members from Jarash Jordan. 

She is requesting a loan of 500 JOD to pay for her home improvements: she would like to do maintenance and repaint her home. In the future she hopes to improve her living standard. Since Zainab is under 30 years old, her loan is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: to pay for her home improvements.

loans.name: Maisoun

texts.en:
Maisoun is a 28-year-old married woman who has three family members from Al Nasser Amman, Jordan. She is requesting a loan of 400 JOD to buy hay and other materials for making her handmade crafts. She would like to increase her products and her income. 

In the future, Maisoun hopes to buy a new home and car. 

Since Maisoun is under 30 years old, her loan is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: to buy hay and other materials.

loans.name: Hadel

texts.en:
Hadel, a 21-year-old single woman from Al Nasser, Amman Jordan, is requesting a loan of 500 JD to buy materials for her salon such as coloring, a hair dryer, etc. Currently working out of her home, she would like to open a beauty salon and eventually buy a car.

Since Hadel is under 30 years old, hers is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: to buy materials for her salon.

loans.name: Asma'a

texts.en: Due to cultural reasons Asma'a prefers that her photo is not on the Internet. Thus, the above photo is of her husband. Asma'a is a 24-year-old married woman from Ashrafia Amman Jordan who has 1 family member. She is requesting a loan of 500 JD to pay for her home improvements. She would like to repaint her home and do maintenance of the home. She hopes in the future to improve her living standard. Since Asma'a is under 30 years old her loan is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: to pay for her home improvements

loans.name: Lana

texts.en:
Due to cultural reasons, Lana prefers that her photo is not on the Internet; thus the above photo is of her husband. Lana is a 28-year-old married woman who has two family members from Jarash, Jordan. She is requesting a loan of 800 JD to buy clothes to resell to her friends and neighbors in the same area. She would like to increase her products to increase her income. 

Since Lana is under 30 years old, her loan is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: to buy clothes to resell

loans.name: Riham

texts.en:
Riham is a 23 year old married female from Al Russeifeh in Amman, Jordan. She has 2 children and has requested a 600 JOD loan to pay for her home improvement expenses. She is planning to buy some furniture and to pay for painting expenses. Riham had previously run a project in the nearby area and in the future she would like to expand it.

Since Riham is under 30 years old, her loan is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: to pay for her home improvement expenses.

loans.name: Hala'a

texts.en:
Hala'a is a 25-year-old married woman from Al Koorah, Jordan. She has two children. Due to cultural reasons, Hala'a  prefers that her photo not appear on the Internet. The photo here is of her husband. 

Hala'a is requesting a 300 JOD loan to pay for home improvement expenses and buy some electronic home devices. Since she is under 30 years old, her loan is a youth loan. In the future, Hala'a would like to add another room to her home.

loans.use: to pay for home improvement expenses and buy electronic home devices

loans.name: Amal

texts.en:
Due to cultural reasons, Amal prefers that her photo not be on the Internet; thus, the above photo is of her husband.

Amal is a 25-year-old, married female from Baqa'a, Jordan. She has four children. She has requested a loan of 800 JOD to pay for her home improvement and painting expenses. In the future, she would like to build an upper floor for her children and pay for their education.

Since Amal is under 30 years old, her loan is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: to pay for her home improvement expenses

loans.name: Tasneem

texts.en:
Due to cultural reasons, Tasneem prefers that her photo not be on the Internet; thus the above photo is of her husband.

Tasneem, a 25-year-old married woman from Al Zarqa in Jordan, has requested a 400 JOD loan to pay for retailing in cosmetics and accessories. She would like to expand her enterprise and have her own small shop in order to improve the living conditions of her family.

Since Tasneem is under 30 years of age, hers is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: to pay for retailing in cosmetics and accessories.

loans.name: Hussam

texts.en:
Hussam is a 22-year-old single male from Hay Nazal in Jordan.  Hussam requested a 500 JOD loan to pay for his home improvement expenses.  In the future he wants to renew the furniture and have his own business.

Since Hussam is under 30 years old, his loan is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: pay for home improvement expenses

loans.name: Bara'a

texts.en: Bara'a is a 21-year-old single female from Sahab in Jordan. She has requested a 700 JOD loan to pay for her home improvement and painting expenses. Because Bara'a is under 30 years old, her loan is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: to pay for her home improvement expenses

loans.name: Narjes

texts.en:
Narjes is a 29-year-old married woman from Ashrafia, Amman, Jordan who has 4 family members. She is requesting a loan of 500 JD to pay for materials for her salon. She would like to buy a machine for hair and skin. She wants to develop her project and open a salon to increase her family's income.

Since Narjes is under 30 years old her loan is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: to pay for materials for her beauty salon

loans.name: Wafa'a

texts.en: Wafa'a is a 24-year-old married woman who lives with two family members in Al Russeifeh, Jordan.  She is requesting a loan of 700 JOD to pay for her home improvements.  She would like to buy new furniture and do maintenance to the home.  In the past she repainted her home. In the future she hopes to expand her home.  Since Wafa'a is under 30 years old her loan is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: to pay for her home improvements

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy hoes and fertilizer, and pay the labourers.

loans.name: Luvy Jeaneth

texts.es: Luvy Jeaneh de 27 anos de edad, casada con un hijo de 4 anos. Luvy es originaria de la localidad del jicaral, lugar que esta ubicado en la zona norte del país. Luvy siempre se ha caracterizado por ser una mujer muy responsable, trabajadora, de buena costumbre. Ella ya ha tenido crédito con Fundación león 2000 y ha demostrado ser responsable con sus pagos en tiempo y forma. La actividad económica de Luvy es la venta de ropa y cosméticos de forma ambulante y tiene clientela de fija y eventuales. La rutina diaria de Luvy es salir a vender a la calle 10 horas diarias para entregar la mercadería por encargo, la cual recupera la ganancia quincenalmente. El financiamiento lo esta solicitando para invertir en capital de trabajo y surtir su pequeño negocio y aprovecha porque se acercan la temporada con mayores venta por las promociones y temporada navideña. Con el financiamiento comprara camisas, pantalones, short, faldas, pinturas labias, perfumees, crema hidrates de cuerpo.  Luvy agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva les brindan a personas de escasos  recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener un medio de vida digno.
texts.en: Luvy Jeaneh is 27 years old, married and has a 4-year-old son. She is originally from Jicaral, which is in the northern part of the country. Luvy has always been known for being a very responsible, hardworking and well-mannered woman. She has had loans with Kiva partner Fundación León 2000 and has been responsible with her payments. Luvy makes a living selling clothing and cosmetics on the streets and has a regular customer base. Her routine is to go out to sell on the street 10 hours a day and deliver her goods, and she collects her payments every other week. She is requesting the loan to stock her small business and take advantage of the time of year when sales peak around Christmastime. She plans to purchase shirts, pants, shorts, skirts, lipsticks, perfumes, and body lotions. Luvy is grateful for the help Kiva lenders provide to people of scant resources in countries like Nicaragua so they can have a decent life.

loans.use: to purchase shirts, pants, shorts, skirts, lipstick, perfumes, and body lotions.

loans.name: Alejo

texts.es:
El señor Alejo es de la comarca llamada el Zapote, Teustepe ha  trabajado por varios periodos con MiCrédito desde los grupos solidarios  obtuvo su primer crédito de Kiva el cual le ayudo ya que pudo realizar sus trabajos de siembra de maíz, frijol y trigo y pagar la mano de además compro abono y refrescante que utilizó en el cultivo del frijol. 
Está requiriendo un segundo crédito don alejo lo quiere para pagar mano de obra para dar limpieza y mantenimiento de los potreros y comprar alambre para reparar los cercos.  Al estar los potreros limpios sin monte nacerá mejor el pasto y las vacas paridas que tiene darán mas leche  para hacer las cuajadas don alejo dice que su próximo crédito seria para comprar los insumos y abono para la siembra de frijol y maíz.
texts.en: Alejo is from the Zapote, Teustepe region and has worked with MiCrédito a number of times since taking out his first Kiva loan, which helped him with farming corn, beans and wheat by allowing him to pay for labor and purchase fertilizer for his beans. He is requesting another loan to pay workers to clean and maintain his fields as well as purchase wire to fix his fences. Keeping his fields clean will improve the grass, and the young calves that he has will produce more milk to make curds. Alejo says that his next loan will be to purchase supplies and fertilizer to plant corn and beans.

loans.use: to pay workers to clean and maintain his fields and to purchase wire to fix his fences.

loans.name: Denis Isaac

texts.es: Denis Isaac de  45 anos de edad, soltero con cuatro hijos de 12, 7, 5,3 anos. Él es originario de Malpaisillo lugar que esta ubicado en la zona norte del país, Malpaisillo se caracteriza por una zona agrícola. Denis es un hombre muy responsable, trabajador, con ganas de salir adelante en la vida por sus pequeños hijos para brindarle un futuro mejor. Él tiene por actividad económica un taller de ebanistería el cual consisten en la elaboración de mueble de madera y hierro, negocio que lo tiene ubicado en   un lugar especifico de su localidad. Experiencia en el negocio 3 anos. Negocio que surgió por la necesidad de tener una fuente de trabajo para poder sostener a su familia y brindarle la seguridad que necesitan. El financiamiento lo necesita para invertir en capital de trabajo y surtir su negocio en la compra de madera  y hierro para la elaboración de muebles. Denis Isaac agradece la ayuda que le brindan los inversionistas kiva a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener fuentes de trabajo digna.
texts.en:
Denis Isaac, 45, is single and has four children, ages 12, 7, 5 and 3.  He is from Malpaisillo which is located in the northern part of the country.  Malpaisillo is known for being an agricultural region.  Denis is a very responsible, hard-working man who is determined to get ahead in life for his small children, and to give them a better future.  He has a carpentry shop, in a specific location in town, where he makes furniture out of wood and iron.  He has been in business for three years and started it to have a source of income to support the family and provide the necessary security.

He is in need of a loan for working capital and to stock his company with wood and iron to make furniture.  Denis Isaac is grateful for the help Kiva lenders give to people with scarce resources in poor countries such as Nicaragua so they can have decent jobs.

loans.use: To buy wood and iron to make furniture.

loans.name: Viola

texts.en:
Viola lives in the Eldoret area of Kenya, which is home to the main campus of Moi University. She has three children and has been doing this work for seven years.  Her primary income sources are eggs, crops, and personal work.

She stated what is most enjoyable about farming: "Being her own boss!" Her biggest challenge is "Sometimes during the dry season the crops don't do well and the animals too lack food." The animal on the farm is named "Lelmet".She will use the loan to buy irrigation pipes.

Viola was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied: "Got news from a client in Kitale."  She was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: "Juhudi's unique loan products."

Her highest monthly expense is farming costs. When asked how this loan will benefit your family, Viola replied, "From the loan she will be able to invest and thus increase her asset base."

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Viola owns the following:  a cow and poultry but does not own a pig, a pump, a bicycle, a motorcycle, or an automobile. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household a mosquito net and a sewing machine but does not have electricity, solar power, running water, TV, or a DVD.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and sent the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To purchase irrigation pipes

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en:
Benjamin lives in the Eldoret area of Kenya, which is extremely fertile for agriculture. He has seven children. His primary income sources are milk, eggs, crops, and personal work, and he has been doing this work for 17 years.

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming: "He loves being his own boss and from farming this has been made possible!" His biggest challenge is "During dry season it is difficult to get food for the animals."  Animals on the farm have been given the names of "Miso".He will use the loan to buy a water tank.

Benjamin was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: "Got information from other members." This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: "Various loan products from Juhudi; policies."

His highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked how this loan will benefit your family, Benjamin replied, "With an additional cow his income will be greatly increased."

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Benjamin owns the following:  a cow, poultry, a pump, and a bicycle, but does not own a pig, a motorcycle, or an automobile. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household a mosquito net, but does not have electricity, solar power, running water, a sewing machine, TV, or a DVD.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and sent the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To purchase water tanks for irrigation.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is married and has one daughter. She lives with her life partner in their own house in the community of Msambweni.

Fatuma has her own vegetable stall, selling a variety of fresh fruits and vegetables. She established her business in her home one year ago. Her customers prefer her goods because of the quality and freshness of her fruits and vegetables.

She is currently requesting her second loan cycle, which is for 20,000 KES (Kenyan shillings). She will use the loan to buy more fruits and vegetables such as bananas, tomatoes, cabbages, potatoes, kale, etc.

Her goal is to increase sales, to manage to have funds saved, and to give her daughter a quality education.

loans.use: to buy more fruits and vegetables such as bananas, tomatoes, cabbages, potatoes, kale, etc.

loans.name: Exequiel

texts.es:
Exequiel, un humilde campesino de 52 años, habitante de la comunidad El Bálsamo, Teustepe, padre de 3 hijos. Él se dedica a la siembra de maíz, trigo y frijol, lleva de 35 años trabajando en esta actividad, la cual aprendió por tradición pues sus padres se dedicaban a lo mismo. Toda su producción la vende en la misma comarca, además aprovecha a sembrar más en invierno, para almacenar granos básicos durante el verano pueda enfrentar la escases de estos productos y de esta manera no dejar de vender a buen precio y tener para consumo del hogar. 
Está requiriendo el financiamiento para comprar insumos, abonos y pagar mano de obra para sembrar frijol y maíz. Espera darle un mejor mantenimiento a sus cosechas. Una vez que  cancele su crédito, invertirá en comprar 2 terneros.
texts.en:
Exequiel, 52, is a humble farmer who lives in the community of El Bálsamo in Teustepe.  He has three children.  He grows crops such as maize, wheat and beans, and has been in this activity for 35 years, as he learned the trade from his parents.  He sells all of his produce around the area where he lives; and he plants more in the winter time to be able to store basic grains during the summer in case there is a lack of product.  This way he can keep his prices low and also have enough for home consumption.

He is requesting a loan to buy supplies and fertilizers, and to hire workers to plant beans and maize.  He hopes to be able to provide better maintenance for his crops.  As soon as he pays off the loan, he plans to buy two calves.

loans.use: To buy supplies and fertilizers, as well as hire workers to plant beans and maize.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca, 23, lives together with her friend in West Point. She stopped her education in the tenth grade and has a son that is five months old. 

She has been involved in this business for the past two years: she has a table in the market where she sells body spray, body cream, body powder, hand cream, lip stick and body wash. She learned to sell from her friend because of her good interactions with her customers; they always come in to buy. 

She is requesting this loan to purchase more body spray, body cream, hand wash, body powder and lip stick for the business. She plans to give her son a better education.

loans.use: to purchase more body spray, body cream, hand wash, body powder and lip stick for the business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 32 years old, married, and has two children. To earn a living she sells second-hand clothes. She has been in the business for four years. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has grown her business because she has been trained on business management skills.

Mary's desire is to own a boutique in the future. 

She needs a loan of 4,000 KES to buy an energy-saving cooker for personal use.

loans.use: to buy an energy-saving cooker.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy dry fish and more fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah is 25 years old and lives in Buchanan. She is single and has four children between the ages of 2 and 8. All of her children attend school and live at home.

For the past 10 years, Deborah has been selling cosmetics in the local market. She is requesting a loan to purchase more cosmetics for her business. She plans to be a successful businesswoman in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more cosmetics for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy additional stock of cosmetics and to purchase shavers.

loans.name: Dama

texts.en:
Dama is a married businesswoman who lives in Malindi. She is the mother of five children, all of whom are in school.  She sells coconut leaf roofing material, commonly referred to as "makuti." Makuti is preferred for roofing in the Malindi area and along the coast generally, since it insulates the house from the heat, mainly experienced during the daytime. She has been running this business for ten years. She also sells fish and keeps goats.
Dama was introduced to Milango by her friends and is applying for a loan of 41,900 Kenya shillings to purchase more coconut leaves, fish and goats. Her main challenges are high inflation, which has reduced the purchasing power of most of her customers, and a shortage of reliable customers.
Dama will save the additional income generated with this loan and use it to provide for her family.

loans.use: To buy coconut leaf roofing material for resale, fish to sell and goats to raise.
